author: Allen
title: Manipulating the symbolic meaning of meat to encourage greater acceptance of fruits and vegetables and less proclivity for red and white meat
brief_description: Being told of a scientific study that people who endorse social hierarchy and who embrace human dominance over nature are more likely to eat meat
notes: finds that people who reject hierarchy and dominance in the treatment group reduce their meat consumption but red and white meat consumption between the groups overall "remained constant" despite a rise in the fruits and veggies consumption rising in the treatment group. This is what the authors report. However table 4 tells us that actually the treatment group saw a meaningful reduction in red and white meat consumption and also highly differential treatment by treatment condition with Ns they don't report elsewhere. On the other hand, table 3 reports a tiny reduction in average servings per week that doesn't correspond to that result at all. The data analysis in this paper is a mess and the outcome is very crude (self-reported "increaesd fruits and veggies consumption in the last week?"). We could theoretically take table 4 as the canonical result but I think it makes more sense to just call this an unspecified null. If the authors had provided a SD of meat consumption in table 3 we'd be somewhere but lacking that I don't think we should take the authors at face value when they say that there was no effect.

author: Bianchi
title: Replacing meat with alternative plant-based products (RE-MAP): a randomized controlled trial of a multicomponent behavioral intervention to reduce meat consumption
intervention_condition: four weeks of free meat substitutes and information and recipes
outcome: grams of meat eaten per day
notes: perfectly fine study

author: Carfora (b)
title: Randomised controlled trial of a text messaging intervention for reducing processed meat consumption: The mediating roles of anticipated regret and intention
brief_description: daily text message reminders to promote the self-monitoring of processed meat consumption
notes: I suppose there is an argument for excluding this on the basis that we want to show *lasting* effects i.e. those that endure beyond treatment itself. But we included studies like this in the contact and prejudice metas and it does at least show that text messages produce more than a momentary effect

author: Carfora
title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
brief_description: daily messages on the expected consequences of low red and processed meat consumption (RPMC) on either health, the environment, or both health and the environment.
notes: "A confirmation of the effects in further studies is warranted before the findings can be generalized to all young adults." Indeed!

author: Carfora (a)
title: Correlational study and randomised controlled trial for understanding and changing red meat consumption: The role of eating identities
brief_description: daily text message reminders to promote the self-monitoring of red meat consumption
notes: this study seems *very* similar to the other Carofa 2017 paper but I believe they're different samples & outcomes.

author: Coker
title: A dynamic social norm messaging intervention to reduce meat consumption: A randomized cross-over trial in retail store restaurants
brief_description: exposure to a social norm message (“More and more [retail store name] customers are choosing our veggie options”)
outcome: dynamic descriptive social norm message intended to motivate a shift from meat-to plant-based meals at an in-store restaurant at a major chain: "More and more [retail store name] customers are choosing our veggie options"
notes: the implementation issues here are a cautionary tale about field experiments, but still it's good that they actually published the data

author: Cooney
title: Do Online Videos of Farmed Animal Cruelty Change People’s Diets and Attitudes?
brief_description: advertising campaign to lead people to a landing page with a video of farmed animal cruelty
country: internet (US, UK, Canada, Australia, and other)
notes: commentary here: https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/arrsdtar9sqL4AvzG/more-thoughts-and-analysis-on-the-mercy-for-animals-online#Was_the_experimental_group_inspired_to_change_their_attitudes_about_animals_. Also I'm calculating SD from the confidence intervals which I don't like but it's what we've got

author: Emmons (a)
title: Project PREVENT: A Randomized Trial to Reduce Multiple Behavioral Risk Factors for Colon Cancer
brief_description: education targeting behavioral risk factors for colorectal cancer among individuals who have been diagnosed with adenomatous colon polyps
notes: this outcome measure is pretty crude -- did a risk factor stay the same, increase, or decrease. food diary much more reliable. Also, it's borderline excludable because its methods aren't replicable -- the specific changes to the microenvironment “were not reported in detail, precluding more detailed analyses of this intervention." Alas. Finally, noting here that it's stratified random assignment rather than cluster.

author: Emmons (b)
title: Cancer Prevention Among Working Class, Multiethnic Adults: Results of the Healthy Directions–Health Centers Study
brief_description: social-contextual approach tar- geting multiple levels of influence on behaviors, with special attention to low literacy skills and the shared and unique features of culture across racial/ethnic groups
outcome: red meat consumption (RMC) -- 3 or fewer servings per week
notes: Fine study; this and the other Emmons et al. 2005 paper are identified herein as "companion studies" and both are part of the " Harvard Cancer Prevention Program Project"

author: Epperson
title: Information Avoidance and Moral Behavior: Experimental Evidence from Food Choices
brief_description: 360° video about the living conditions of pigs in intensive farming via a virtual reality (VR) headset
outcome: proportion of meals that had meat subsequently purchased at the university canteen
notes: kind of a doozy integrating this one because of the WTP component but I think that because they randomly assign the 'price' of the video, we effectively have equivalence between treatment and control. It's also very tempting to code this as an unspecified null because the effects 7 days later are totally null and there's a bit of a spike in vegetarianism and then a moderate backlash. but instead I'm taking them at face value when they say that the WLS and AIPW estimators overall show an effect of about 6%, which I'm assuming is cumulative. This also corresponds to the abstract, where they say there was a decline of "6 to 9 percentage points in university canteens" of meat eating. I'm not seeing any estimators in the 9% range but whatever. I think 6% is a reasonable point estimate for a study that provides a *lot* of different estimators (it's also effectievely the DiD estimate b/c apparently there were baseline differnces in meat consumption)

author: Fehrenbach
title: Designing Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption: A Test of the Extended Parallel Process Model
brief_description: watching a high threat/low efficacy video on the dangers of meat consumption
outcome: Behavior Proxy – Last 7 Days Meat Frequency
notes: nice and intuitive example of how social desirability bias might influence results

author: Fehrenbach
title: Designing Messages to Reduce Meat Consumption: A Test of the Extended Parallel Process Model
brief_description: watching a high threat/ high efficacy video on the dangers of meat consumption with guidelines for reducing meat consumption
outcome: Behavior Proxy – Last 7 Days Meat Frequency

author: Feltz
title: Educational interventions and animal consumption: Results from lab and field studies
brief_description: advocacy pamphlet, an advocacy video, and two philosophical ethical papers that argue against consuming animals
notes: I'm grouping all the intervention conditions into one because of similar enough theory and results. Basicaly one condition created positive change and three created a backlash. There are a *lot* of dependent variables here and I think the overall conclusion of "null" or "statistical noise" is basically right

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: alternating between a vegetarian option (‘VegFirst’) and a meat option (‘MeatFirst’) being placed first in line, that is, nearest the cafeteria entrance

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: alternating between a vegetarian option (‘VegFirst’) and a meat option (‘MeatFirst’) being placed first in line, that is, nearest the cafeteria entrance

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: alternating between a vegetarian option (‘VegFirst’) and a meat option (‘MeatFirst’) being placed first in line, that is, nearest the cafeteria entrance

author: Garnett
title: Order of meals at the counter and distance between options affect student cafeteria vegetarian sales
brief_description: alternating between a vegetarian option (‘VegFirst’) and a meat option (‘MeatFirst’) being placed first in line, that is, nearest the cafeteria entrance

author: Garnett
title: Impact of increasing vegetarian availability on meal selection and sales in cafeterias
brief_description: Doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available from 25 to 50% at a cafeteria at an English university
outcome: increased vegetarian meal sales (and decreased meat meal sales)

author: Haile
title: Changing Hearts and Plates: The Effect of Animal-Advocacy Pamphlets on Meat Consumption
brief_description: receiving an animal-advocacy pamphlet that specifically requested that people refrain from eating meat to improve the wellbeing of farmed animals.
notes: I am not thrilled to be backing out an SD from the SE but that's what we've got. Substantively the result is right; it should be about a null and it'll show up that way

author: Hennessy
title: The impact of information on animal product consumption
brief_description: factual leaflets modeled after those used by animal advocacy organizations worldwide
outcome: number of days in the past seven days meat was consumed when asked in the follow-up

author: Hennessy
title: The impact of information on animal product consumption
brief_description: factual leaflets modeled after those used by animal advocacy organizations worldwide
outcome: number of days in the past seven days meat was consumed when asked in the follow-up
notes: very nice study. SD and DIM clearly stated and all other varibles too. Cites MHE which is good signal. should emali this person to talk about our review https://www.linkedin.com/in/seanrhennessy/. Also like that they tell us the average cluster size (1.6)

author: Jalil
title: Low-cost climate-change informational intervention reduces meat consumption among students for years
brief_description: 50 min talk about the consequences of meat consumption for climate change, alongside information about the health benefits of reduced meat consumption
outcome: meal selection at the dining hall
notes: landmark study

author: Lacroix
title: Targeting interventions to distinct meat-eating groups reduces meat consumption
brief_description: various appeals to reduce meat consumption based on personal appeals and goal-setting
notes: this study is hard to interpret because of all the grouping and such but basically I'm taking them at face value with the data reported from the combined treatment groups where they report a null effect. Also maybe a good example of excluding vegetarians problem (it's reasonable but it also might upwardly bias the results)

author: Mathur
title: Effectiveness of a Theory-Informed Documentary to Reduce Consumption of Meat and Animal Products: Three Randomized Controlled Experiments
brief_description: 20-minute documentary (Good For Us) produced by The Humane League
outcome: report on past week's consumption using a  modified version of the National Cancer Institute’s Dietary Health Questionnaire III

author: Mathur
title: Effectiveness of a Theory-Informed Documentary to Reduce Consumption of Meat and Animal Products: Three Randomized Controlled Experiments
brief_description: 20-minute documentary (Good For Us) produced by The Humane League
outcome: report on past week's consumption using a  modified version of the National Cancer Institute’s Dietary Health Questionnaire III
notes: great study and we'll highlight with a meta-analytic test for "what if we penalize all the self-reported stuff by estimate of SDB from study 2 of Mathur et al. 2021"

author: Norris
title: Booklet Comparison Study – Pay Per Read #1 Dec 2014
brief_description: participants read https://veganoutreach.org/wp-content/uploads/PPR-2015-YC.pdf
notes: follow up reports that the results weren't unidirectional and weren't distinguishable from null: https://veganoutreach.org/wp-content/uploads/PPR-Follow-Up-Nov-2014.pdf

author: Norris
title: Booklet Comparison Study – Pay Per Read #1 Dec 2014
brief_description: participants read https://veganoutreach.org/wp-content/uploads/PPR-2015-EI.pdf

author: Peacock
title: Which Request Creates the Most Diet Change: A Reanalysis
brief_description: leaflets with  vegan, vegetarian, less meat and combination messages respectively further subidivided into leaflets of different lengths
notes: I am having trouble making sense of the re-analysis  but I take them at their word when they say: "The study did not detect any significant differences between the vegan, vegetarian, less meat, combination or control groups on any of the measured changes in diet."

author: Piazza
title: Monitoring a meat-free pledge with smartphones: An experimental study
brief_description: commitment to a meat free pledge
notes: Ns are a bit of a guess -- they assign by cluster but don't tell us how many clusters, just that clusters average 2-8. so I'm saying average cluster is 5 and dividing the total N of each by 5

author: Piester
title: “I'll try the veggie burger”: Increasing purchases of sustainable foods with information about sustainability and taste
brief_description: students at a university cafe saw a "screen with a picture of a veggie burger and the label “Sustainable Choice."
notes: This study could have been analyzed and presented in a much clearer way. For anyone who cares about ATE, we need n_t, n_c, the treatment group mean, and the control group mean, for all three conditions. I guess it's fine to split by gender but then tell us how many of each gender were assigned to treatment and controlz, and to which treatments! So just to be easy here I'm dividing the total number by 4 which means that I'm assuming totally equally assignment

author: Piester
title: “I'll try the veggie burger”: Increasing purchases of sustainable foods with information about sustainability and taste
intervention_condition: study two sustainability plus veggie burgers taste good
brief_description: students saw both messages
notes: This one is hard to classify according to my theory distinctions because it's both. It could be put under either.  I'm goign to call it mainly environmental just to make the analysis tractable (because this will also appear under the sub-category of persuasion in a follow-up analysis

author: Piester
title: “I'll try the veggie burger”: Increasing purchases of sustainable foods with information about sustainability and taste
intervention_condition: study two veggie burgers taste good
brief_description: students at a university cafe saw a screen that said "The garden fresh veggie burger is a tasty choice! In a taste test we did at the [name of cafe], 95% of people said that the veggie burger tasted good or very good! Consider giving the garden fresh veggie burger a try today!"

author: Piester
title: “I'll try the veggie burger”: Increasing purchases of sustainable foods with information about sustainability and taste
brief_description: labeling that told patrons how sustainable on a 0 to 5 scale the itemss at a university cafeteria were
outcome: number of leaves associated with the food items participants purchased (a close proxy for vegetarianism)
notes: Women show a significant result but men don't, but still, it's positive effect overall I thnk because the women participants show pretty large changes. illustrative about the challenge of measuring "delay" in these kins of field experiments. it's a nci study and it took place over four days but we have no idea if that means we had delayed outcome. but on the other hand we want to know the effects of these kinds of interventions. Should I exclude? Not sure. talk to Don

author: Polanco
title: The Relative Effectiveness of Different Approaches to Animal Advocacy
brief_description: assigned to view one of ten forms of animal advocacy in a survey
notes: is this online? double-check before publication

author: Sorensen
title: Promoting Behavior Change Among Working-Class, Multiethnic Workers: Results of the Healthy Directions–Small Business Study
intervention_condition: cancer prevention intervention designed to prompote healthy behaviors
brief_description: "integrated inter- ventions focused on nutrition, physical activ- ity, and occupational health and activities focused on individual risk factors"
outcome: </= 3 servings of red meat per week
notes: nice study; too bad it found so little. Authors self-report it did not achieve statistical significance (the multivitamin effect was significant but there are a lot of tests being run here. for this outcome p = .72

author: Sparkman
title: Developing a Scalable Dynamic Norm Menu-Based Intervention to Reduce Meat Consumption
brief_description: dynamic norm message added to the menu
outcome: a meal's having meat or not
notes: I like this study because of its very nice design but its statistical resutls are a bit hard to integrate into a meta-analysis. I'm not seeing much in the way of baseline or population standards for proportion of vegetarian meals on a control day. What we really want is proportion of vegetarian meals ordered on the treatment days minus proportion of vegetarian meals ordered on control days without covariates and we want both data points reported. Instead we have z scores which are beta / se and theoretically se = sd / sqrt(n) assuming no covariates (which there are) so hypothetically we can convert z to via z/sqrt(n). However before we publish for real let's see if we can get to the bottom of this.

author: Sparkman
title: Developing a Scalable Dynamic Norm Menu-Based Intervention to Reduce Meat Consumption
brief_description: dynamic norm added to a sit down restaurant's lunch menu
outcome: a meal's having meat or not

author: Sparkman
title: Developing a Scalable Dynamic Norm Menu-Based Intervention to Reduce Meat Consumption
brief_description: dynamic norm added to a sit down restaurant's lunch menu
outcome: a meal's having meat or not
notes: Studies 3 and 4 are the gold standard for field experiments in this literature, and if you average them together, it's a big fat null

author: Sparkman
title: Developing a Scalable Dynamic Norm Menu-Based Intervention to Reduce Meat Consumption
brief_description: dynamic norm in an online restaurant
outcome: a meal's having meat or not

author: Sparkman
title: Cut back or give it up? The effectiveness of reduce and eliminate appeals and dynamic norm messaging to curb meat consumption
brief_description: randomized to read one of three op-eds: a reduce op-ed, an eliminate op-ed, or a control op-ed on a topic unrelated to meat consumption
notes: very nice study
